title: AB 575
content: The State of California enacts the following. The State of California enacts Section 60200 of the Education Code, amending it to require the state board to adopt basic instructional materials for kindergarten and grades 1 to 8 in subject areas like language arts. At least five materials must be adopted for each grade level, with restrictions on the timing of adoption for certain subjects. The State of California requires the state board to adopt basic instructional materials for various subject areas including language arts, mathematics, science, social science, bilingual or bicultural subjects, and other disciplines deemed necessary. Timing restrictions are in place for the adoption of materials in specific subject areas. The State of California mandates the adoption of basic instructional materials for subjects like language arts, mathematics, science, social science, bilingual or bicultural subjects, and other disciplines as determined necessary by the state board. Procedures are in place for the submission of instructional materials. The state board in California mandates the adoption of instructional materials for various subjects, including language arts, mathematics, science, social science, and other disciplines as deemed necessary. Procedures are established for the submission of these materials, with limitations on resubmission if no substantive changes are made. If a publisher or manufacturer submits revisions to instructional material after the specified timeframe, the department will assess a fee not exceeding the costs for review. Instructional materials must be adopted or rejected within six months, with a possible extension of three months for complex materials or unforeseen circumstances. The review process for instructional materials involves committees with volunteer content experts and teachers from various grade levels and subjects. The adoption rules are transparent and applicable to all formats of materials. The state board uses specific criteria to ensure submitted materials meet standards. The state board reviews and adopts instructional materials based on specific criteria to ensure they align with the curriculum framework, comply with state guidelines, are factually accurate, and meet content standards. Instructional materials must be factually accurate, aligned with state content standards, and should not include unnecessary exposure to commercial brands unless deemed necessary for educational purposes by the state board. The use of commercial brand names, products, or logos in instructional materials must be necessary for educational purposes as defined by state guidelines. Incidental appearance in illustrations is allowed. Additional criteria may be established by the state board to align with constitutional and statutory requirements. If basic instructional materials are rejected, the state board must provide a written explanation based on established criteria. The board may use materials written by the Superintendent or other advisers. The state board can adopt fewer than five basic instructional materials if less than five are submitted. The state board may adopt fewer than five basic instructional materials in each subject area for each grade level if fewer than five materials are submitted or if they do not meet the criteria. The board must review the evaluation process if fewer materials are adopted. This section does not limit the board's authority to adopt non-basic instructional materials. The state board may adopt fewer than five basic instructional materials in each subject area for each grade level if fewer than five materials are submitted or if they do not meet the criteria. The board must review the evaluation process if fewer materials are adopted. This section does not limit the board's authority to adopt non-basic instructional materials. The state board shall prescribe procedures to provide open and flexible materials submission system that cater to diverse pupil populations and represent cultural pluralism. The state board adopts instructional materials and provides a listing with unit costs for procurement. The list remains available until a new curriculum framework is adopted. Lists are categorized by subject and grade level, accessible to school districts, and posted on the department's website. The state board adopts instructional materials based on a new or revised curriculum framework. Lists of adopted instructional materials are categorized by subject and grade level, accessible to school districts, and posted on the department's website. The lists include information from review committees and may include publisher details for basic information, copyright protection, or third-party content identification. The state board may adopt regulations for exceptions, and the Superintendent will develop guidelines for implementation. Section 60227 of the Education Code defines followup adoptions and requires notice before conducting them in a subject area. Before conducting a followup adoption in a subject area, the department must post a notice on their website and notify publishers. Publishers participating will be assessed a fee based on the number of programs and grade levels submitted for review. The fee will cover the cost of the followup adoption process, with efforts made to keep it modest and avoid duplicating work from the primary adoption. Before incurring substantial costs for the followup adoption, the department requires publishers or manufacturers to declare intent to submit specific programs for review, specifying grade levels. A fee is assessed, payable even if programs are withdrawn or grade levels reduced. Submission will not be reviewed until the fee is paid in full. The Legislature intends for the fee for follow-up adoption to not be prohibitive for small publishers or manufacturers. Small publishers or manufacturers can request a fee reduction. Small publishers and manufacturers are defined as independently owned businesses with 100 or fewer employees and average annual gross receipts of $10 million or less. Revenue from fees will be used for adoption and instructional material review costs. The revenue from fees charged for follow-up adoption will be used for adoption and instructional material review costs. If there is little interest from publishers and manufacturers, a follow-up adoption may not be conducted. General fund revenue cannot be used for follow-up adoption costs. This section will be in effect until January 1, 2024, unless extended or repealed by a later statute.
